hook.text: Marshall McLuhan said the light bulb is a medium with no content. Yet it changed how civilization works.

topics.title: Agenda Setting: What Media Tells You to Think About

hook.text: Media may not tell you what to think. But it's remarkably good at telling you what to think about.

buildup.text: McCombs and Shaw's agenda-setting theory: the issues media covers most become the issues the public considers most.

discovery.text: If a news channel covers crime 24/7, viewers believe crime is rising â€” even when statistics show it's falling.

twist.text: What media doesn't cover matters equally. Issues absent from coverage become invisible to public consciousness.

climax.text: Media literacy means asking: 'Who decided this was news? What's being covered â€” and what's being ignored?'

punchline.text: The news doesn't show you the world. It shows you a selection of it.

quiz.question: What does agenda-setting theory describe?
options: Media tells people what to think
Media influences what people think about by choosing coverage topics

topics.title: Framing: How the Same Story Changes Meaning

hook.text: 'Tax relief' vs. 'tax cuts for the wealthy.' Same policy. Different frame. Different public reaction. That's framing.

buildup.text: Framing is selecting certain aspects of reality and making them more prominent to promote a particular interpretation.

discovery.text: Kahneman and Tversky showed that framing a surgery as '90% survival' vs.

twist.text: All media is framed. There's no 'view from nowhere.' The question isn't whether framing exists, but whose frame you're.

climax.text: Media-literate consumers don't just consume the frame. They identify it, consider alternatives, and ask who benefits.

punchline.text: Every story has a frame. See the frame, and you see the story differently.

quiz.question: What is media framing?
options: Selecting aspects of reality to promote a particular interpretation

topics.title: The Attention Economy: You Are the Product

hook.text: 'If you're not paying for the product, you are the product.' Your attention is the most valuable commodity in media.

buildup.text: Herbert Simon coined 'attention economy' in 1971: information consumes attention, and attention is scarce.

discovery.text: Social media platforms earn money per second of your attention.

twist.text: Outrage, fear, and novelty capture attention most effectively.

climax.text: Media literacy in the attention economy means understanding that everything you see is optimized to keep you scrolling.

punchline.text: When attention is currency, every app is a pickpocket.

topics.title: The Cultivation Theory: TV's Slow Drip

hook.text: Heavy TV viewers believe the world is more dangerous than it is. George Gerbner called it 'Mean World Syndrome.'

buildup.text: Cultivation theory: long-term media exposure gradually shapes viewers' perceptions of reality to match media portrayals.

discovery.text: Gerbner found that heavy TV viewers overestimate crime rates, distrust strangers more, and see the world as scarier.

twist.text: The effect isn't dramatic. It's a slow drip â€” tiny shifts in perception that accumulate over years of consumption.

climax.text: Social media may amplify cultivation effects: personalized feeds create micro-realities that feel like the whole truth.

punchline.text: Media doesn't brainwash you in a day. It reshapes you a drip at a time.

quiz.question: What is Gerbner's 'Mean World Syndrome'?
options: Heavy TV viewers believing the world is more dangerous than it is

buildup.text: World War I was the first war where governments systematically used mass media to shape public opinion and recruit.

discovery.text: The Committee on Public Information, led by George Creel, used posters, films, and speakers to manufacture war support.

discovery.text: The technique: repeat a lie often enough and it becomes accepted truth.

twist.text: Many Germans were educated and intelligent. Propaganda doesn't work because people are stupid.

topics.title: Conspiracy Theories: Why Smart People Believe

hook.text: Flat Earth. Moon landing hoax. QAnon. These aren't beliefs of the unintelligent â€” some believers have PhDs. Why?

twist.text: Debunking often backfires. Challenging a conspiracy activates identity defense â€” the belief is part of who they are.

topics.title: Confirmation Bias: The Filter You Don't See

hook.text: You Google a question and click the first result that agrees with you. The other nine? Invisible.

buildup.text: Confirmation bias is the tendency to seek, favor, and remember information that confirms your existing beliefs.

discovery.text: It's not just what you seek. It's what you notice: your brain literally filters out information that contradicts your.

twist.text: The smarter you are, the better you are at rationalizing your biases.

climax.text: The antidote: actively seek opposing viewpoints. Read the source you disagree with most.
